title.narrative: Decision on Amendment of Contribution December 2020

description.narrative: 2018 marked the first year (out of three) of the project supported by the Embassy, aimed at supporting CSOs and social movements to implement projects that are aimed at promoting good governance and increasing citizen’s awareness and demand for human rights in Zambia. During year one (August – December 2018), several achievements were made relating to setting up partnerships and the operating structures for the projects implementation. Particularly, AAZ developed and sent out the call for proposals; established a Technical Evaluation Committee (TEC) with the role to assess applications received in line with AAZ´s existing policies and tools; set up a Project Accountability Team (PAT) with the function to review and award grants recommended by the TEC; Shortlisting applications received and segmenting them against thematic priorities and grants type; and AAZ conducted proposal review workshops targeting the organizations selected after the field assessment. Although the inception phase of the program was successful, AAZ experienced some challenges. Some of these were linked to much higher turnout of proposals than expected, planned and budgeted for; low quality of applications from rural CSOs; and that the manual proposal submission process led to higher workload than anticipated. Learning from these will be key as the project grows. These issues have been discussed with AAZ, and the following mitigation measures have been set up/planned: AAZ received 249 proposals in the first call for proposals, against the overall project expected target of 41. As this turn out needed adequate staff time and resources to review and provide feedback to all the applicants, AAZ could for example only issue a public announcement on applicants who made it to the next stage and only deal with those who sent specific queries/request for comments on their proposals. Lesson learnt: calling for full proposals is not the best strategy. Rather, the introduction of expression of interest in the next call will lessen the work overload and only filter relevant concept notes to a full application stage. So, to ensure that AAZ are able to adequately manage and review all proposals, they will introduce a concept note stage for the next call. AAZ also noted that staff who are not specifically recruited for the project, spent a lot of their time on its implementation. Thus, during the Annual Review AAZ indicated that they may need to adjust how much of the budget is going to admin costs. AAZ noted a low quality of applications from rural CSOs, making it difficult for them to compete for the funding. As civic participation in rural Zambia is already particularly low, a special focus is needed for this target group. Accordingly, AAZ plans to provide additional support to rural CSOs. Overall, social movements, community groups and other CBOs faced big challenges in competing for the grants. AAZ will need to develop the mechanisms to effectively support this form of partnership. One idea discussed during the Annual Review Meeting is to develop a separate criterion for CSOs run by key populations (e.g. by youths, disabled, LGBTIQ, etc) and for CBOs. Another example is that AAZ had met very rural women-groups, who do a lot of good work around e.g. empowerment and participation, but consist of members who are illiterate. Therefore, there is no way for them to write a proposal that meets the projects current minimum requirements, despite having good projects. Can there be a way to include such groups in the grant? Perhaps it would be possible to accept certain recorded proposals? Can the project establish and make better use of other fiscal agents in the districts, to assist these very small organisations with managing grants? During May 2019, the Embassy travelled with AAZ to see projects supported under the Sida grant. A number of observations were made: Many small grants for short time periods are being awarded; What impact can realistically be achieved under these premises? Going forward, the Embassy will need to consider if we are satisfied with the goal to contribute to a vibrant civil society, or if we have a higher ambition level for the impact we want the Swedish grant to have on governance, gender equality, youth empowerment, etc. I.e. do we want to direct more money to fewer organizations but that are more likely to attain results, or do we want to make sure to reach as many CSOs (particularly in rural areas where civic participation is very low) as possible? On the other hand, the Community Action grant and the Innovation Grant can be seen as a first step on a ladder, where organizations can progress towards qualifying for the Standard Grant (longer term, bigger volumes). In other words, although a three-month grant to a small CBO may be unlikely to achieve the shorter-term results, it can be seen as a longer-term investment, training e.g. youths in advocacy work and civic engagement, and perhaps setting the grounds for a stronger CBO in the future. AAZ training and capacity building will be important here – simply providing funding does not appear to be effective, so the tailored trainings will fill a key role. We will need to follow-up with AAZ what type of support they will be providing to these smaller community based CSOs/CBOs. The question also arises if the organizations are able to absorb the funds, as they are not able to use funds after the activity period expires. For example, Mpulungu Youth Vision, which the Embassy visited, are receiving ZMW 100,000 over three months. This seems to be a lot of money to absorb for a very small organization given the time-frame. The Embassy also sampled some agreements signed between AAZ and sub-grantees. The Embassy noted that there is need for AAZ to review their agreement templates to ensure that they make sense for each individual partnership (see details in travel report). For example, it does not make sense to request for quarterly, annual and an end report for a 3-month project.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Programmet ‘Regionalising Urgent Action Fund for Women and Non-Binary Human Rights Defenders in Asia and the Pacific’, genom Urgent Action Funds for Women’s Human Rights in Asia Pacific (UAF AP), syftar till att skydda och stödja kvinnor, icke-binära (t.ex. lesbiska, trans) människorättsförsvarare eller organisationer som står inför akut risk när de försvarar kvinnors och andras mänskliga rättigheter i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. Förslaget gäller ett stöd från Sverige på 1 500 000 SEK, under tidsperioden 1 januari –31 december 2019.
UAF AP är den nyaste medlemmen i det internationella nätverket av UAF systerfonder (Sister Funds), förutom UAF i USA; UAF i Latinamerika och UAF Afrika. UAF AP lanserades 2017 och har ett kontor i Filippinerna och ett i Australien. Stödet bidrar inte bara till att bygga motståndskraft för kvinnors mänskliga rättigheter utan också för att stärka UAF AP:s kapacitet som en regional aktör inom det civila samhället som kan främja mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet i Asien och Stillahavsområdet. Sveriges mervärde bedöms vara bidraget till UAF AP:s institutionella kapacitetsuppbyggnad eftersom bidrag från andra givare inte kan användas särskilt för att förbättra organisationens ekonomiska styrning och ledning.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The program ‘Regionalising Urgent Action Fund for Women and Non-Binary Human Rights Defenders in Asia and the Pacific’, by Urgent Action Funds for Women’s Human Rights in Asia Pacific (UAF AP) aims to provide protection and support to women, nonbinary (e.g., lesbian, trans) human rights defenders or organisations that face urgent risk in their advocacy to uphold women’s human rights and human rights in Asia and Pacific. It is proposing the support from Sweden 1 500 000 SEK, during 1 January-31 December 2019.
UAF AP is the newest member of the international network of UAF sister funds, apart from UAF in USA; UAF in Latin America and UAF Africa. UAF AP was launched in 2017 with offices in Philippines and Australia. The support is not only contributing towards resourcing resilience for women’s human rights but also strengthening the capacity of UAF AP as a regional civil society actor to promote human rights and gender equality in Asia and the Pacific. The institutional capacity building is deemed as the Sweden’s added value in which other donor foundations cannot support especially on improving the financial management of the organization.

description.narrative: IRC reported the following results, according to agreed objectives:1) Women generate income and assets, and are able to use and control resources,2) Women and girls shape and contribute to their communities and homesand 3) Women and girls are protected from and supported to recover from the consequences of GBV. Achieved progress and challenges of the programme implementation were captured in IRC's reports, including mitigations of the effects of the social unrest in Lebanon and of the Corona pandemic on the programme through adaptation of the activities and resources. Some undermet objectives were identified by IRC, admitting when a planned target may have been over-ambitious in the initial planning, like the potential profit that was expected to be sustained from creating and supporting micro-businesses in Jordan. The economic situation in Jordan does not leave much room for running businesses successfully. IRC recognizes as well that, in the case of North Lebanon (Wadi Khaled), the planned expected economic opportunities were not matching the reality of this excluded area. In this marginalized territory whose population doubled with the Syrian refugee influx in 2013, IRC has been confronted to the limited capacities of the local civil society, of the markets and existing businesses, to the lack of socioeconomic opportunities and at the same time to a very conservative culture. However, despite limitations of their economic dividends, beneficiaries are acquiring new skills and self-confidence that bring a significant difference to their lives. Our assessment is that IRC provides challenged persons, households and communities with both recovery opportunities and resilience through high quality and 'client'-tailored services that are relevant and on high demand, especially in this time of economic crisis. The ongoing crisis in Lebanon (closure of businesses, depressed markets, job destructions, inflation) and the lockdown situations in both countries since March 2020 are however significant obstacles to the empowerment objectives of IRC's programme. IRC shared with us data on decreasing job opportunities being offered by the market. IRC learnt a lot about factors that were unidentified in the planning phase throughout the implementation phase. IRC could however adapt the programme by recognizing the programme challenges and making possible adjustments at an early stage. IRC is an organization able to reflect on itsself and to adapt with agility. It is noticeable that IRC is generally meetings its result targets, with few exceptions, and that during year 2, it accelerated achievements in order to catch up with delayed results. Results under the target for combined year 1 and 2 may be slightly below expectation due to lower implementation during year 1 and despite reinforced implementation during year 2. In many cases, results are above targets. Interesting and unexpected cooperation experiences with local actors that the programme has generated, were shared by IRC, like the ad hoc training requested by the Jordanian police school from IRC for GBV case management and psychosocial counselling techniques, and like the facilitating role of the municipality of Wadi Khaled in Lebanon in promoting the programme among the population. IRC played there the role of a development actor of proximity, funding with another donor's resources repairs to the municipal sewage system that made cooperation even more easier afterwards for other interventions. The feedback of beneficiaries about the programme gives indications of positive transformations it brought into their lives: men learning to share decision-making with their spouse, women getting conflict resolution or anger management skills, women and girls acquiring technical skills and increasing their employability, girls negotiating successfully the delay of their too early marriage, etc. A particular character of the programme that defines its success is the way all services and activities are integrated with one another and complementary so that maximum benefit is achieved. Committed trainees may be recruited as volunteers and benefit from a per diem allowance. Mothers may leave their infants at the kindergarten while attending training or counselling sessions. GBV services and empowerment services are integrated, removing the potential stigma of attending a center for case management of GBV. Persons seeking such services are offered as well, like other people and without being identified as GBV survivors, training and socioeconomic opportunities that make the visit to the center casual and unnoticed. The programme benefits to other family members as well who may attend lifeskills sessions, focus group discussions on gender roles, and improve ability to sustain livelihoods and employability. Another particularity of IRC programme is that it is tailored on the beneficiary herself/himself who is more perceived as an agent of the implementation whose opinion is listened to than a recipient. The experience of visiting IRC-run centres, as the embassy has done at several occasions, brings a sense of high spirit and dynamism among both personal and clients, opposite of victimization, and the impression that things have already started to get better for them despite their life situation as refugees. An obstacle for which IRC has found mitigation measures during year 3 is the cost of transport barriers from the community to the centres. IRC has introduced the distribution of taxi vouchers for women and girls living at a too long distance for sustaining their attendance. IRC has also reorganized the services and the curricula in more compact schedules at convenient time of the day so that beneficiaries optimize their time spent at the centre. The overall impression of the programme confirms Sida's positive assessment of this partnership. It is meeting a priority need in areas of socioeconomic exclusion. It delivers demand-driven and a wide offer of concrete services to the beneficiaries, based on a continuous dialogue with them and reassessement of the progress and relevance of the programme. It addresses GBV and socioeconomic hardship, which are interrelated, in a holistic manner.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Oxfam Novib har ansökt om SEK 190 miljoner av Sida för SeedsGROW 2 som sträcker sig under perioden 2019–2024. SeedsGROW 2 är den andra fasen och fotsättningen på den nuvarande SeedsGROW 1 som Sida bidragit till med SEK 171 miljoner under perioden 2013–2018. Några lärdomar från fas 1 som Oxfam bygger den andra fasen på är arbetet med Farmer Field Schools och hur dessa kan utvecklas samt hur kampanjen runt matens värdekedja har ökat förståelsen bland konsumenter, företag och regeringar. SeedsGROW 2 kommer bestå av två komponenter ”Sowing Diversity = Harvest Security” (SD=HS - SEK 128 miljoner) och ”GROW” (SEK 62 miljoner). SD=HS kommer att implementeras i sju länder (Guatemala, Peru, Nepal, Laos, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Zambia) och i Kina som en lärande partner. Genom att arbeta nära Kinas experter inom fröförädling (forskning och policy) kan förfinande metoder och modeller användas i de andra länderna. Kina är en ’hot spot’ vad gäller agro-biodiversitet och ursprungsland för flera av de grödor som programmet fokuserar på (tex hirs).
GROW kommer implementeras i fyra länder (Brasilien, Pakistan, Thailand och Uganda). Brasilien, Pakistan och Thailand är exportörer av olika globala varor och viktiga för många företag som GROW kampanjen riktar sig till där målet är att belysa de stora ojämlikheter som påverkar fattiga matproducenter. I båda programmen så kommer Oxfam Novib aktivt vara engagerad med andra givare som arbetar globalt, regionalt och på landnivå för att finansiera och komplettera den förslagna Sidabudgeten. Den övergripande ambitionen är att nå 40 länder med en total budget på EUR 77 miljoner.
Oxfam Novib är en del av Oxfams konfederation, som är ett internationellt förbund av 20 medlemsförbund vars syfte är att uppnå större genomslag genom samarbete. Oxfam Novib är den näst största grenen i konfederationen och ansvarar för att tillhandahålla affärsmässigt stöd och rekrytering av Oxfampersonal i 14 utvecklings- och tillväxtländer. Oxfam Novib är också implementeringspartner i flera andra länder över hela världen och bidrar till Oxfams landsstrategi med kompetens, liksom genomförande av projekt i dessa länder. Tillsammans arbetar Oxfam i över 90 länder och alla anslutna landkontor delar en gemensam vision och filosofi för att bekämpa fattigdom och orättvisor, som en del av en global förändringsrörelse.
Visionen för den andra fasen av SeedsGROW är att bidra till ett globalt matproduktionssystem som är rättvist och hållbart, stödjer småskaliga producenters rättigheter - män och kvinnor, garanterar mat- och nutritionssäkerhet och som förespråkar hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser och biologisk mångfald i kontexten av ett förändrat klimat. Oxfam har identifierat tre huvudsakliga utmaningar relaterade till SDGs som programmet adresserar och dessa är: utmaningen med hållbar livsmedels produktion – tillräckligt med mat måste produceras samtidigt som de planetära gränserna inte överskrids (SDG 2, 6, 12, 13, 14 ,15); resiliensutmaningen – de mest sårbara måste stärkas för att kunna hantera klimatförändringar och kompenseras för effekterna (SDG 1, 2, 13, 15); jämlikhetsutmaningen – rikedom och makt måste balanseras i matvärdekedjan (SDG 1, 5, 8, 9).
Målgruppen för både SD=HS och GROW är urfolk och småjordbrukare – kvinnor, män och ungdomar. Komponenterna är:
a). SD = HS är ett initiativ med flera berörda parter som överbryggar traditionell och vetenskaplig kunskap för innovativa och rättvisa frösystem för utsäde. SD=HSs fokus är att förbättra lokalt producerat utsäde som är anpassat till behov och preferenser hos småskaliga jordbrukare och ursprungsfolk. Detta för att bidra till att uppnå mat- och nutritionssäkerhet både lokalt och globalt och att brukarna ska kunna använda sina rättigheter och ha en utökad kapacitet att få tillgång till, utveckla och använda växtgenetiska resurser.
Insatsens Theory of Change (ToC) visar hur programmets fyra delar förväntas leda till målsättningen och visionen. Visionen är ett globalt livsmedelssystem som är rättvist och hållbart, som stödjer bönders rättigheter och livsmedelstrygghet samtidigt som det skyddar naturresurser, biodiversitet i jordbruket och är anpassat till klimatförändringar.
Målsättningen för programmet är att urfolk och småbönder åtnjuter sina rättigheter och har kapacitet att få tillgång till, utveckla och använda växtgenetiska resurser för att förbättra sin livsmedelstrygghet, inklusive livsmedlens näringsvärde, trots klimatförändringar.
De fyra pelare som programmet består av, inkluderade som fyra outcomes i theory of change, förväntas vara ömsesidigt stärkande och bidra till den övergripande målsättningen.
Outcome/pelare 1, Stärkande av bönders plantdiversitet, ämnar göra urfolk och småbönders samhällen mer motståndskraftiga genom tillgång till, användande och förvaltning av växtgenetiska resurser både gällande livsmedelstrygghet, nutrition, katastrofriskhantering och anpassning till klimatförändringar.
Outcome/pelare 2, Marknader, ämnar stärka försörjningstrygghet och säkrad tillgång till fröer genom skapande av och tillgång till marknader för högkvalitativa fröer som är anpassade till böndernas behov.
Outcome/pelare 3 kallas NUS, Neglected and Underutilized Species. Det förväntade resultatet är att stärka lokalsamhällens resiliens genom att öka matens nutritiva värde genom främjande av NUS och därigenom stärkt biodiversitet, vilket också är bra för hälsa och lokalsamhällets resiliens.
Outcome/pelare 4, policies och institutioner, har som målsättning att skapa ett stöd bland intressenter för möjliggörande politiskt och institutionellt ramverk för bönders frösystem och implementering av bönders rättigheter.
b). GROW är ett påverkansprojekt med målet att ändra det rådande matproduktionssystemet genom att uppmuntra och stödja offentliga och privata aktörer att revidera policyer och praktik. Nyckelområden som adresseras är markrättigheter, klimatförändringar och ojämlikheter i matens värdekedja. Detta förutses gynna kvinnliga småskaliga matproducenter och deras samhällen. De två komponenterna är fristående från varandra men Sida kommer i dialog uppmuntra till sökande efter synergier utifrån förväntade resultat.
Visionen för Grow II är densamma som för SD= HS. Deras Theory of Change (ToC) är problemfokuserad, och fokuserar på kvinnliga matproducenter och deras lokalsamhällen, som i ökande grad påverkas av klimatförändringar, och har osäkra landrättigheter och inkomster, samt små möjligheter till påverkan. Grundorsakerna presenteras som tre utmaningar inom hållbar livsmedelsproduktion, resiliens och jämställdhet med tre fokusområden för projektet: matvärdekedjor, landrättigheter och klimatförändringar. Det baseras på antagandet att framsteg i dessa områden ger påtagliga resultat för kvinnliga småbönder och deras lokalsamhällen inom de definierade utmaningarna. Insatsens långsiktiga mål är att skapa en global rörelse för "food justice" med målet att privata och offentliga policies främjar deras intressen.
På global nivå har Oxfam Novib det huvudsakliga ansvaret för genomförande av aktiviteter och att leverera resultat. Även kopplingarna lokalt-globalt och att länka aktiviteter i länder med den globala nivån sker genom denna centrala koordinering. För SD=HS kommer Oxfam samarbeta med en lång rad strategiska partners så som FAO, CGIAR, utsädesföretag med flera. Inom GROW sker arbetet med bland annat lantbruksorganisationer och kvinnoproducentgrupper, dagligvaruhandel och matföretag, offentlig och privat finansiell sektor samt multilaterala institutioner. Finansiella överföringar sker framförallt till andra Oxfamenheter och kontor. På nationell nivå kommer projektimplementering ske via Oxfams landkontor och partners för båda projektkomponenterna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Oxfam Novib has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 190 millions towards the SeedsGROW 2 program for the 2019-2024 period. SeedsGROW 2 is an extension and continuation of the current SeedsGROW 1 program to which Sida contributes with a total of SEK 171 millions during the 2013-2018 period. There are some lessons learned from Phase 1, as Oxfam prepares for phase 2. These are; the importance of the Farmer Field Schools and how these can evolve, and how the campaign around the food value chain has increased understanding among consumers, businesses and governments. SeedsGROW 2 will consist of two components "Sowing Diversity = Harvest Security (SEK128 millions) and GROW (SEK 62 millions). SD = HS will be implemented in seven countries (Guatemala, Peru, Nepal, Laos, Uganda, Zimbabwe and Zambia), and in China as a learning partner. By working close to China's seed processing export (research and policy), refining methods and models can be used in other countries. China is a 'hot spot' in terms of agro-biodiversity and it is a country of origin for several of the crops that the program focuses on (eg millet).
GROW will be implemented in four countries (Brazil, Pakistan, Thailand and Uganda). Brazil, Pakistan and Thailand are exporters of various global goods and are important to many companies targeted by the GROW campaign, where the goal is to highlight the major inequalities affecting poor food producers. For both programs, Oxfam Novib is actively engaging with other donors working on the global level, as well as on program country and regional levels to fundraise and complement the proposed Sida funding. The overall ambition is the program to be implemented in more than 40 countries with a total budget of EUR 77 millions.
Oxfam Novib is part of the Oxfam confederation, an international confederation of 20 affiliates whose aim is to achieve greater impact by working together in collaboration with others. Oxfam Novib is the second-largest affiliate in the confederation and is responsible for providing business support and contracting of Oxfam staff in 14 developing and emerging countries. Oxfam Novib is also a partner affiliate in several other countries worldwide, contributing to the Oxfam country strategy with expertise, as well as implementing projects in those countries. Together, Oxfam works in over 90 countries and its affiliates share a common vision and philosophy to fight poverty and injustice, as part of a global movement for change.
The overall objective of SeedsGROW 2 is to contribute to a global food system that is just and sustainable, that supports the rights of small-scale food producers- men and women-, that guarantees food and nutrition security and that promotes the sustainable management of natural resources and biodiversity within the context of a changing climate. Oxfam has identified three main challenges related to SDGs and whose main aims are to create sustainability and ownership by the local or indigenous people; Sustainable Production Challenge - enough food must be produced at the same time as the planetary limits are not exceeded (SDG 2, 6, 12, 13, 14, 15); Resilience Challenge - The most vulnerable must be empowered to adapt to climate change and be compensated for the damages (SDG 1, 2, 13, 15); Equity Challenge - wealth and power need to be balanced in the food value chain (SDG 1, 5, 8, 9).
The target groups for both SD = HS and GROW are indigenous peoples and small farmers - women, men and youths. The components are: a). SD = HS is a multi-stakeholder initiative that bridges traditional and scientific knowledge for innovative and fair seed systems. SD = HS's focus is on improving locally produced seeds that are adapted to the needs and preferences of small-scale farmers and indigenous people. This helps to achieve food and nutrition safety both locally and globally, and that users can use their rights and have increased capacity to access, develop and use plant genetic resources.
The initiative's Theory of Change (ToC) shows how the four parts of the program are expected to lead to the goal and vision. The vision is a global food system that is fair and sustainable, which supports the rights and food security of locals while protecting natural resources, biodiversity in agriculture and adapting to climate change.
The objective of the program is that indigenous people enjoy their rights and have the capacity to access, develop and use plant genetic resources to improve their food security, including food nutritional value, despite climate change.
The four pillars of the program, including four outcomes in the theory of change, are expected to be mutually reinforcing and contribute to the overall objective.
Outcome / Pillar 1, Strengthening of Plant Diversity, aims to make indigenous peoples and small-scale communities more resistant through access to, use and management of plant genetic resources, both in terms of food safety, nutrition, disaster management and adaptation to climate change. Outcome / Pillar 2, Markets - aims to strengthen security of supply and secure access to seeds through the creation and availability of markets for high quality seeds adapted to farmers' needs. Outcome / Pillar 3 is called Neglected and Underutilized Species (NUS) - the expected result is to strengthen the resilience of local communities by increasing the nutritional value of food through the promotion of NUS, thereby strengthening biodiversity, which is also beneficial to health and community resilience. Outcome / Pillar 4, Policy and Institutions aims to provide stakeholders support for the possible political and institutional framework for banding seed systems and implementation of farmer’s rights.
b). GROW is an impact project aimed at changing the current food production system by encouraging and supporting public and private actors to revise policies and practices. Key areas to be addressed are land rights, climate change and inequalities in the food value chain. This is expected to benefit women small-scale food producers and their communities. The two components are separate from each other, but Sida will in dialogue with Oxfam Novib, encourage search for synergies based on expected results.
The vision for Grow II is the same as for SD = HS. Their Theory of Change (ToC) is problem-focused, focusing on female food producers and their local communities, which are increasingly affected by climate change, and have insecure land rights and incomes, as well as small opportunities for impact. The root causes are presented as three challenges in sustainable food production, resilience and gender equality with three focus areas for the project: food value chains, land rights and climate change. It is based on the assumption that progress in these areas gives tangible results for female farmers and their local communities within the defined challenges. The long-term goal of the initiative is to create a global movement for food justice with the goal of promoting private and public policies.
At global level, Oxfam Novib has the main responsibility for implementing activities and delivering results. The local-global links and activities in countries globally are diligently done by Oxfam. For SD = HS, Oxfam will collaborate with a wide range of strategic partners such as FAO, CGIAR, and seed companies. Within GROW, work is done with agricultural organizations and women producer groups, food retailers and food companies, public and private financial sectors and multilateral institutions. At the national level, project implementation will be done through Oxfam's national offices and partners for both project components.

The overall objective of the phase 2 programme is to contribute to a global food system that is just and sustainable, that supports the rights of small-scale food producers- men and women-, that guarantees food and nutrition security and that promotes the sustainable management of natural resources and biodiversity within the context of a changing climate. By the end of the project, women small-scale food producers will benefit from policy and practice change that empowers them to address injustices in the food value chains, increases their resilience to climate impacts and contribute to secure and equitable land rights. Medium to long term changes envisioned by SD=HS and which form the core of the Theory of Change are: Pillar 1: through self – sustaining Farmer Field Schools and over 35,000 grassroots master trainers, resilient indigenous and farming communities are better able to access and sustainably use plant genetic resources for food and nutrition security, climate change adaptation and disaster management. Pillar 2: by contributing towards a farmer inclusive market, indigenous peoples and small-holder farmers enhance their livelihoods, income and seed security through improved production of and improved policies on market access to high-quality seeds of diverse crops and varieties. Pillar 3: by understanding and addressing the hunger period, rural communities have strengthened their coping strategies by increasing the intake of nutritious food based on local biodiversity and improved management of neglected and underutilized species (NUS). Pillar 4: by providing evidence in support of farmers’ seed systems, Policy makers, seed industry and other stakeholders support an enabling policy and institutional environment for farmers’ seed systems and the implementation of Farmers’ Rights. Participatory Knowledge Management: though larger scale documentation, farmers’ access and use of information, and targeted communication materials, SD=HS will further enable reach out and facilitate exchange of knowledge and seed and foster greater cooperation of multiple stakeholders engaged in plant genetic resources for food and agriculture. By the end of the project at least 215,000 households in indigenous and farming communities will have benefitted. The target is that at least 50% of these beneficiaries will be women. The overall objective of the GROW project component is to contribute to a diverse and active movement for food justice across the world and to ensure women small-scale food producers and their communities benefit more from local, national and global public and private sector policies that ensure their food security and that protect and promote their prosperity and resilience. Long term changes envisioned by GROW are; globally and nationally operating food companies share power and wealth more equally in their supply chains, contributing to a poverty-free food system. Oxfam will encourage key private sector actors in the agri-food systems to improve their policies and practices in the areas of land rights, climate change and food value chains; public and private financial sector actors prioritize projects that support women small-scale food producers and their communities, that respect land rights and that are aligned with the goals of the Paris Agreement. Oxfam will engage with International Financial Institutions and other globally relevant Financial Institutions to ensure better alignment with international benchmarks, and leverage progress in their lending standards to encourage governments and others to do so; governments address the needs of women small-scale food producers and their communities, particularly those affected by climate change, through pro-poor climate adaptation plans, finance for irreversible loss and damage as result of climate change, and secure and equitable land rights. Sida assesses that the planned objectives of the intervention are plausible. There is simply a clear logic between the objectives.

description.narrative: This Sida contribution contributes to different levels, i.e. global/normative level [GLOB/NORM], at national/institutional level [NAT/INST] and actors/target group [ACT/TG] of the Theory of Change (ToC) of the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in sustainable economic development 2018-2022. It also contributes to four of its strategic objectives: ECO 2.1 – Strengthened ownership and tenure rights for land and natural resources; ECO 2.2 – Improved conditions for private sector development, sustainable business and responsible and sustainable investments and innovations; and ECO 2.3 – Increased productivity and sustainable production in agriculture, forestry and fisheries, including food security; and ECO 2.4 – Strengthened women's economic empowerment; It also contributes to three objectives in the Strategy for Sweden’s global development cooperation in the areas of environmental sustainability, sustainable climate and oceans, and sustainable use of natural resources 2018–2022. Namely: ENV 1.2 – Reduced vulnerability of people living in poverty as well as increased resilience to manage climate change and natural disasters; ENV 2.1 – Enhanced protection and rehabilitation, and sustainable management and use of land-based ecosystems, biodiversity and species, natural resources, including agriculture and forestry, as well as ecosystem services. ; and ENV 2.5 – Sustainable production and consumption patterns, including preventive chemical control and waste management. The target group of the programme, the smallholder farmers, are directly involved in the programme for the SD=HS part, whilst indirectly impacted for the GROW part of the programme. SD=HS reports results based on 4 outcomes and GROW based on 3 pathways. These results also show a connection to GLOBECs and GLOBENs objectives, as well as GLOBECs ToC (or how they “channel” change). Results from SD=HS (Seeds) SD=HS objective is: “Indigenous peoples and smallholder farmers enjoy their Farmers’ Rights and have the capacity to access, develop and use plant genetic resources to improve their food and nutrition security under conditions of climate change”. SD=HS operates in seven countries (Guatemala, Laos, Nepal, Peru, Uganda Zambia and Zimbabwe) and one learning country (China). Country level examples [NAT/INST] [ACT/TG] Outcome 1: Farmers’ crop diversity management, and the full outcome is: “Resilient indigenous and farming communities are better able to access and sustainably use and maintain plant genetic resources for food and nutrition security, climate change adaptation and disaster management”. The countries that are included under this outcome are China (linking and learning only), Guatemala, Laos, Nepal, Peru, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Accordingly, the outcome is on track, having reached approximately 7,300 farmers, which is also the targeted number, and are working to develop new crop varieties in 300 Farmer Field Schools (FFS) on participatory plant breeding across seven countries [NAT/INST] [ACT/TG]. On an outcome level, support through agricultural extension and training via the FFS and access to more nutritious and locally adapted seeds, enables the target groups to be food secure, and improve their livelihoods. This has also allowed the smallholder farmers to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The result under this outcome reports to several of the tagged objectives under both GLOBEC’s and GLOBEN’s strategy, but majorly to ECO 2.3 and ENV 2.1. Outcome 2: Farmer seed enterprises, and the full outcome is: “Indigenous peoples and smallholder farmers enhance their livelihoods, income and seed security through improved production or market access to high-quality seeds of diverse crops and varieties, which are adapted to farmers’ needs and preferences”. The countries that are included under this outcome are Nepal, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Activities under this outcome have encountered some challenges as a result of extreme weather events, such prolonged droughts and erratic rainfall. Oxfam reports, amongst others, that ca. 7,300 farmers have directly accessed quality seeds, and received organisational development support followed by capacity building / technical assistance [ACT/TG]. According to Oxfam’s Annual Report, the 2019 production season was challenging for Zimbabwe’s Champion Seeds cooperative, due to the country’s continued economic downturn and erratic rainfall. As a direct consequence, less seed was produced in 2019: a total of 84 MT of climate-smart seed was marketed and diffused to marginal regions where smallholder farmers reside. The cooperative maintained a 100% seed certification rate – that is, all seeds successfully passed inspection. With nine seed varieties, including farmer varieties, suitable for the agro-ecological regions where smallholder farmers live, Champion Seeds’ crop portfolio is more diverse than that offered by other seed shops. The maize, small grain and legume seed crops produced by the Farmer Seed Enterprises (FSE) are drought tolerant and early-maturing varieties, suitable for production in low-rainfall environments. This supported smallholder farmers in marginal regions in Zimbabwe to adapt to the impacts of climate change and at the same time gain access to markets to sell the products, which has improved the smallholder farmers livelihood situation in times of extreme weather events [ACT/TG]. Outcome 2 results essentially reports to ECO 2.3; ENV 1.2; and ENV 2.1. Results from cross-cutting areas under SD=HS - YOUTH: In this second phase of SD=HS, Oxfam reports a stronger involvement of youth in the programme activities. Approximately 30% of the direct ‘beneficiaries’ are youth (< 35 years), and higher than the initial target of 25%. A major success factor was the establishment of youth-led FFS, with activities specifically targeting the younger generation. For example in Zimbabwe, youth-led FFS hosted sessions on the use of mobile applications for agriculture [NAT/INST] [ACT/TG]. The youth-led FFS integrated a focus on market linkages as a way to involve young people migrating back from urban areas. The objective is to ensure that youth have the possibility during the programme period to develop and establish youth-led agri-businesses. This result can be tied to the following objectives for respective strategy: ECO 2.2; ECO 2.3; and ENV 1.2. Global level examples [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG] Outcome 3: Nutrition and local food plants, and the entire outcome is: “To strengthen the coping mechanism of the households (men and women) participating in the program by improving access to and use of local food plants, in particular neglected and underutilized species (NUS)”. Under this outcome, Oxfam reports on progress against the uptake of producing local food plants and nutrition by smallholder female farmers via the FFS approach. 1,112 farmers benefitted directly from the work under this outcome. Results also show that smallholder farmers are increasingly using NUS, particularly under food scarcity periods, to build resilience, ensure food security and that the target groups get access to healthier and more nutritious foods. In this context, the programme is working a lot to change / alter norms around NUS across regions where the SH=HS is present [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. The result under this outcome reports to numerous of the tagged objectives under respective strategies, but mainly to: ECO 2.3; ECO 2.4; and ENV 2.1. Outcome 4: An enabling policy environment, and the complete outcome is: “Policymakers and other stakeholders support an enabling policy and institutional environment for farmers’ seed systems and the implementation of Farmers’ Rights, through improved policies and practices”. This is a normative outcome, and reports on results from local to global level. One interesting highlight from 2019 is the Adoption of the Guidelines for the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Farmers’ Varieties and Landraces by the Commission on Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (CGRFA). The guidelines now make proper reference to the importance and rights of smallholder farmers in creating and conserving local crop diversity. These guidelines aim to assist countries in developing national plans for the conservation and sustainable use of farmers’ varieties [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. Reported results of outcome 4 can be connected to the following strategic objectives: ECO 2.1; ECO 2.2; ECO 2.3; and ENV 2.1. Results from cross-cutting areas under SD=HS - GENDER: SD=HS have developed a plan to integrate female leadership in its existing methodology, learning, and research tool. As a result, the programme has opted to include local methodologies within Oxfam’s Gender Action Learning System (GALS). Oxfam reports on some results related to representation. Thus, Sida asked Oxfam to further elaborate on how SD=HS addresses social and gender norms, with a clearer tie to Women’s Economic Empowerment (WEE). Accordingly, the SD=HS have integrated the GALS methodology in the FFS ‘toolbox’. There are different exercises within this field guide, where some exercises aim at revealing precisely difference in norms, rules and social expectations [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. These results explicitly report to ECO 2.4 and the policy marker on gender equality (marked as significant). Results from GROW The objective of GROW is: “To contribute to a diverse and active movement for food justice across the world and to ensure that women small-scale food producers and their communities benefit more from local, national, and global public and private sector policies that ensure their food security and the protect and promote their prosperity and resilience”. The GROW campaign operates at a global level, in over 30 countries. The GROW programme uses funds from Sida to support three pathways globally and nationally in Brazil, India, Pakistan, Thailand, and Uganda. Pathway 1: “Globally and nationally operating food companies share power and wealth more equally in the supply chains, contributing to a poverty-free food system in which the millions of women and men who grow, produce and process the food are able to claim their rights and thrive”. Outcomes under this pathway are on track. This pathway specifically works with the BehindtheBarcodes / Price campaign and the rights of small-holder farmers to produce food sustainably. It also emphasises on farmers’ worker rights. The geographical focus of this pathway is Brazil, India, Thailand and global. Example of interesting campaigning (advocacy work) under Pathway 1: “In the first half of 2019, Oxfam engaged with supermarkets targeted in the Behind the Barcodes / Price campaign, which was launched in 2018 with an initial focus on the abuse of seafood workers’ human rights. The second scorecard, covering the 16 biggest retailers in Europe and the US, was issued on 3 July 2019. It updated scores on supermarkets’ transparency and accountability, and how they ensure workers’ rights are respected, small-scale farmers are prosperous and resilient, and the women who produce our food are treated fairly” [GLOB/ NORM] [ACT/TG]. The coming annual report 2020 will most likely present possible behavioural changes by the retailers. Results under Pathway 1 can be tagged to ECO 2.3; and ENV 2.1. Pathway 2: “Public and private financial sector actors prioritize projects that support women small-scale food producers and their communities, that respect land rights and that are aligned with the goals of the Paris Agreement”. Outcomes under this pathway are on track and largely emphasises on Oxfam’s advocacy work with banks and other financial institutions on securing land rights through FPIC (Free, Prior and Informed Consent). The geographical focus of this pathway is global. Example of successful strategic advocacy planning, leading to concrete actions changing practices, under Pathway 2: “In August 2019, the report ‘Consent is Everybody’s Business: Why banks need to act on Free, Prior and Informed Consent’ was launched. It will underpin Oxfam’s advocacy with banks and other financial institutions on securing land rights through FPIC. The report focuses on why banks need to have good policies on FPIC, and how they could ensure effective implementation. Philippe Le Houérou, CEO of the IFC, confirmed in October 2019 that it would officially start its pilot voluntary disclosure of high-risk sub-projects under its investments. This was a major milestone for our work on the transparency of financial intermediaries. Oxfam organized a major workshop with 40 participants from civil society on how best to engage and influence IFIs, strengthening alliance work and capacity.” [GLOB/ NORM]. Moreover, in 2019, Oxfam reports to have followed up with the IFC on two initiatives: (a) its Green Equity Strategy (GES), to support its financial intermediary clients’ exit from coal investments; and (b) a voluntary initiative to disclose relevant information of higher-risk sub-projects financed by its financial intermediary clients. The IFC prioritized the development of the GES over the disclosure initiative because transparency in the banking sector is a fairly controversial issue. However, Oxfam reports having pushed the IFC’s management to develop the details of both and seized the opportunity of a hearing before the financial services committee of the US Congress to raise the issue of lack of transparency in IFC intermediaries’ lending. In this way, Oxfam influenced the negotiations with IFC and its most important donor, the US government, especially towards making disclosure a mandatory rule rather than a voluntary one [GLOB/ NORM]. These reported findings explicitly reports to ECO 2.1; ECO 2.2; ECO 2.3; and ENV 1.2. Pathway 3: “Governments address the needs of women small-scale food producers and their communities, particularly those affected by climate change, through pro-poor climate adaptation plans, finance for irreversible loss and damage as a result of climate change, and secure and equitable land rights”. Similar to pathways 1 and 2, this pathway is also on track, with a particular emphasis on climate change-related to land rights. Example of a result under Pathway 3: “In the first week of December 2019, Oxfam and partners launched a large public action under the Land Rights Now campaign highlighting specific cases of criminalized land rights defenders. The campaign – pooling different grants together, among others the Sida one– was built around five cases from Guatemala, Chile, Colombia, the Philippines, and DR Congo. Mobilization events in at least 13 countries put pressure on governments to end the criminalization of land rights defenders” [GLOB/NORM] [NAT/INST] [ACT/TG]. The reported result of Pathway 3 is explicitly linked to ECO 2.1. Moreover, according to the report, the Sida funds have supported the GROW programme to deliver public campaigns and influencing strategies aiming at “fixing” different aspects of the food system that excludes the rights of small-scale farmers. It includes the BehindtheBarcodes/Price campaign and engagement with governments, multilaterals, and International Financial Institutes (IFIs) on climate change and land rights (with a particular emphasis on women’s rights) [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. In 2019 Oxfam has invested more in gender justice and women’s rights by adopting recommendations of feminist influences into GROW’s campaigns (and also includes planning, monitoring, and accountability) [GLOB/NORM]. Oxfam have also engaged in the UNFCCC Gender Action Plan, supporting the participation of women farmers [GLOB/NORM] [ACT/TG]. The summarised results above are majorly tagged to all four of GLOBEC’s strategic objectives, and two out of three of GLOBEN’s strategic objectives, i.e. ENV 1.2 and ENV 2.5. The above summarizes well the results tagged to the different relevant goals in the two different strategies, they also show the goals that in a synergized way contribute to both strategies. For the purpose of facilitating the strategy reporting and other reporting, GLOBEN has decided to clearly report results per relevant strategy goal, as per below (some repetition from above is hence apologized for). 1.2 Reduced vulnerability of people living in poverty as well as increased resilience to manage climate change and natural disasters In the SD=HS project, 7,300 farmers (50% female) in 300 new Farmer Field Schools on Participatory Plant Breeding across the eight countries are working on selection and development of new crop varieties to better cope with shifting market demands and the impacts of climate change, such as droughts and floods. The aim is to develop climate-resilient varieties: for example, an FFS in the flood-prone area of Saravanh province in Laos successfully selected a rice variety with the ability to resist being submerged in flood water. To reduce farmers’ vulnerability to climate change, SeedsGROW has: i) worked with farmers to develop improved seed varieties; ii) engaged with local and national institutions on adaptation plans and NDCs; iii) engaged with global climate talks to influence policies and practices in support of women small-scale food producers and their communities; and iv) engaged with allies and partners such as CAN, WWF, PACJA, FAO, UNEP, Bioversity, IFDC, and Global Crop Trust to develop a more integrated approach to climate resilience. Examples of specific results: - Global progress included governments endorsing a Gender Action Plan to increase women’s participation and leadership in the UNFCCC process, and developing countries at COP25 taking up the demands of Oxfam and other CSOs on loss and damage. - In Pakistan and Uganda, GROW campaigns on climate combined public actions with advocacy to influence governments’ climate change legislation, strategies, and updates to National Determined Contributions (NDCs) to the Paris Agreement. In both countries, Oxfam and partners were actively involved in September’s Greta Thunberg-inspired Global Week for Future. In Uganda the president established a parliamentary committee to start drafting a climate change bill and the NDC. - Oxfam with partners IUCN and WWF mobilized approximately 35,000 small-scale food producers in the three districts (Badin, Thatta and Karachi) to influence district government on implementation of adaptation policies. 2.1 Enhanced protection and rehabilitation, and sustainable management and use of land-based ecosystems, biodiversity and species, natural resources, including agriculture and forestry, as well as ecosystem services The SD=HS reached out to more than 30, 000 farmers and indigenous people in eight countries. 374 Farmer Field schools were established and supported. In these Farmer Field schools, 496 new varieties of over 20 crops made available and 7,300 farmers were trained on plant breeding and crop diversity management improving livelihoods and overall resilience. In 2019, around 33,000 community members in three districts in Southern Pakistan were mobilized with support from GROW through community awareness sessions on preserving mangroves to protect coastal livelihoods. Advocacy towards the provincial government of Sindh was directed towards including in the draft climate change bill providing farmers and rural communities local livelihood diversification options to reduce migration to urban areas. In Uganda, 1,000 people from communities in the kingdom Buganda took action to preserve vulnerable ecosystems such as protection of Lake Victoria and reforestation of degraded areas of Buganda in the light of climate change. 2.5 Sustainable production and consumption patterns, including preventive chemical control and waste management. In Brazil, Oxfam (under the GROW project) and partners organized a roundtable discussion in December 2019 entitled Opportunities and Challenges for a Sustainable Fruit Supply Chain covering due diligence, audits, certification and supply responsibility. Representatives of actors including Tesco (retailer) and Unilever (food processor) met with rural unions and certification bodies such as Rainforest Alliance and Global Gap. In Thailand, which provided cases on human rights abuses faced by seafood workers for the first global public action in 2018, Oxfam and partners continued the national version of the Behind the Barcodes / Price campaign – the “Dear Supermarkets Campaign”. Three retailers made progress especially on transparency: Tesco Lotus, for example, translated and published its human rights in supply chain policies. Major seafood exporters made public commitments on labour rights in a public forum organized by the Ministry of Labour and Oxfam. Results related to thematic perspectives (already mentioned above, but clustered here for easy access) Gender equality SD=HS have developed a plan to integrate female leadership in its existing methodology, learning, and research tool. The guidelines now make proper reference to the importance and rights ofsmallholder farmers in creating and conserving local crop diversity. description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Oxfam Novib har ansökt om SEK 190 miljoner av Sida för SeedsGROW 2 som sträcker sig under perioden 2019–2024. SeedsGROW 2 är den andra fasen och fotsättningen på den nuvarande SeedsGROW 1 som Sida bidragit till med SEK 171 miljoner under perioden 2013–2018. Några lärdomar från fas 1 som Oxfam bygger den andra fasen på är arbetet med Farmer Field Schools och hur dessa kan utvecklas samt hur kampanjen runt matens värdekedja har ökat förståelsen bland konsumenter, företag och regeringar. SeedsGROW 2 kommer bestå av två komponenter ”Sowing Diversity = Harvest Security” (SD=HS - SEK 128 miljoner) och ”GROW” (SEK 62 miljoner). SD=HS kommer att implementeras i sju länder (Guatemala, Peru, Nepal, Laos, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Zambia) och i Kina som en lärande partner. Genom att arbeta nära Kinas experter inom fröförädling (forskning och policy) kan förfinande metoder och modeller användas i de andra länderna. Kina är en ’hot spot’ vad gäller agro-biodiversitet och ursprungsland för flera av de grödor som programmet fokuserar på (tex hirs).
GROW kommer implementeras i fyra länder (Brasilien, Pakistan, Thailand och Uganda). Brasilien, Pakistan och Thailand är exportörer av olika globala varor och viktiga för många företag som GROW kampanjen riktar sig till där målet är att belysa de stora ojämlikheter som påverkar fattiga matproducenter. I båda programmen så kommer Oxfam Novib aktivt vara engagerad med andra givare som arbetar globalt, regionalt och på landnivå för att finansiera och komplettera den förslagna Sidabudgeten. Den övergripande ambitionen är att nå 40 länder med en total budget på EUR 77 miljoner.
Oxfam Novib är en del av Oxfams konfederation, som är ett internationellt förbund av 20 medlemsförbund vars syfte är att uppnå större genomslag genom samarbete. Oxfam Novib är den näst största grenen i konfederationen och ansvarar för att tillhandahålla affärsmässigt stöd och rekrytering av Oxfampersonal i 14 utvecklings- och tillväxtländer. Oxfam Novib är också implementeringspartner i flera andra länder över hela världen och bidrar till Oxfams landsstrategi med kompetens, liksom genomförande av projekt i dessa länder. Tillsammans arbetar Oxfam i över 90 länder och alla anslutna landkontor delar en gemensam vision och filosofi för att bekämpa fattigdom och orättvisor, som en del av en global förändringsrörelse.
Visionen för den andra fasen av SeedsGROW är att bidra till ett globalt matproduktionssystem som är rättvist och hållbart, stödjer småskaliga producenters rättigheter - män och kvinnor, garanterar mat- och nutritionssäkerhet och som förespråkar hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser och biologisk mångfald i kontexten av ett förändrat klimat. Oxfam har identifierat tre huvudsakliga utmaningar relaterade till SDGs som programmet adresserar och dessa är: utmaningen med hållbar livsmedels produktion – tillräckligt med mat måste produceras samtidigt som de planetära gränserna inte överskrids (SDG 2, 6, 12, 13, 14 ,15); resiliensutmaningen – de mest sårbara måste stärkas för att kunna hantera klimatförändringar och kompenseras för effekterna (SDG 1, 2, 13, 15); jämlikhetsutmaningen – rikedom och makt måste balanseras i matvärdekedjan (SDG 1, 5, 8, 9).
Målgruppen för både SD=HS och GROW är urfolk och småjordbrukare – kvinnor, män och ungdomar. Komponenterna är:
a). SD = HS är ett initiativ med flera berörda parter som överbryggar traditionell och vetenskaplig kunskap för innovativa och rättvisa frösystem för utsäde. SD=HSs fokus är att förbättra lokalt producerat utsäde som är anpassat till behov och preferenser hos småskaliga jordbrukare och ursprungsfolk. Detta för att bidra till att uppnå mat- och nutritionssäkerhet både lokalt och globalt och att brukarna ska kunna använda sina rättigheter och ha en utökad kapacitet att få tillgång till, utveckla och använda växtgenetiska resurser.
Insatsens Theory of Change (ToC) visar hur programmets fyra delar förväntas leda till målsättningen och visionen. Visionen är ett globalt livsmedelssystem som är rättvist och hållbart, som stödjer bönders rättigheter och livsmedelstrygghet samtidigt som det skyddar naturresurser, biodiversitet i jordbruket och är anpassat till klimatförändringar.
Målsättningen för programmet är att urfolk och småbönder åtnjuter sina rättigheter och har kapacitet att få tillgång till, utveckla och använda växtgenetiska resurser för att förbättra sin livsmedelstrygghet, inklusive livsmedlens näringsvärde, trots klimatförändringar.
De fyra pelare som programmet består av, inkluderade som fyra outcomes i theory of change, förväntas vara ömsesidigt stärkande och bidra till den övergripande målsättningen.
Outcome/pelare 1, Stärkande av bönders plantdiversitet, ämnar göra urfolk och småbönders samhällen mer motståndskraftiga genom tillgång till, användande och förvaltning av växtgenetiska resurser både gällande livsmedelstrygghet, nutrition, katastrofriskhantering och anpassning till klimatförändringar.
Outcome/pelare 2, Marknader, ämnar stärka försörjningstrygghet och säkrad tillgång till fröer genom skapande av och tillgång till marknader för högkvalitativa fröer som är anpassade till böndernas behov.
Outcome/pelare 3 kallas NUS, Neglected and Underutilized Species. Det förväntade resultatet är att stärka lokalsamhällens resiliens genom att öka matens nutritiva värde genom främjande av NUS och därigenom stärkt biodiversitet, vilket också är bra för hälsa och lokalsamhällets resiliens.
Outcome/pelare 4, policies och institutioner, har som målsättning att skapa ett stöd bland intressenter för möjliggörande politiskt och institutionellt ramverk för bönders frösystem och implementering av bönders rättigheter.
b). GROW är ett påverkansprojekt med målet att ändra det rådande matproduktionssystemet genom att uppmuntra och stödja offentliga och privata aktörer att revidera policyer och praktik. Nyckelområden som adresseras är markrättigheter, klimatförändringar och ojämlikheter i matens värdekedja. Detta förutses gynna kvinnliga småskaliga matproducenter och deras samhällen. De två komponenterna är fristående från varandra men Sida kommer i dialog uppmuntra till sökande efter synergier utifrån förväntade resultat.
Visionen för Grow II är densamma som för SD= HS. Deras Theory of Change (ToC) är problemfokuserad, och fokuserar på kvinnliga matproducenter och deras lokalsamhällen, som i ökande grad påverkas av klimatförändringar, och har osäkra landrättigheter och inkomster, samt små möjligheter till påverkan. Grundorsakerna presenteras som tre utmaningar inom hållbar livsmedelsproduktion, resiliens och jämställdhet med tre fokusområden för projektet: matvärdekedjor, landrättigheter och klimatförändringar. Det baseras på antagandet att framsteg i dessa områden ger påtagliga resultat för kvinnliga småbönder och deras lokalsamhällen inom de definierade utmaningarna. Insatsens långsiktiga mål är att skapa en global rörelse för "food justice" med målet att privata och offentliga policies främjar deras intressen.
På global nivå har Oxfam Novib det huvudsakliga ansvaret för genomförande av aktiviteter och att leverera resultat. Även kopplingarna lokalt-globalt och att länka aktiviteter i länder med den globala nivån sker genom denna centrala koordinering. För SD=HS kommer Oxfam samarbeta med en lång rad strategiska partners så som FAO, CGIAR, utsädesföretag med flera. Inom GROW sker arbetet med bland annat lantbruksorganisationer och kvinnoproducentgrupper, dagligvaruhandel och matföretag, offentlig och privat finansiell sektor samt multilaterala institutioner. Finansiella överföringar sker framförallt till andra Oxfamenheter och kontor. På nationell nivå kommer projektimplementering ske via Oxfams landkontor och partners för båda projektkomponenterna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Oxfam Novib has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 190 millions towards the SeedsGROW 2 program for the 2019-2024 period. SeedsGROW 2 is an extension and continuation of the current SeedsGROW 1 program to which Sida contributes with a total of SEK 171 millions during the 2013-2018 period. There are some lessons learned from Phase 1, as Oxfam prepares for phase 2. These are; the importance of the Farmer Field Schools and how these can evolve, and how the campaign around the food value chain has increased understanding among consumers, businesses and governments. SeedsGROW 2 will consist of two components "Sowing Diversity = Harvest Security (SEK128 millions) and GROW (SEK 62 millions). SD = HS will be implemented in seven countries (Guatemala, Peru, Nepal, Laos, Uganda, Zimbabwe and Zambia), and in China as a learning partner. By working close to China's seed processing export (research and policy), refining methods and models can be used in other countries. China is a 'hot spot' in terms of agro-biodiversity and it is a country of origin for several of the crops that the program focuses on (eg millet).
GROW will be implemented in four countries (Brazil, Pakistan, Thailand and Uganda). Brazil, Pakistan and Thailand are exporters of various global goods and are important to many companies targeted by the GROW campaign, where the goal is to highlight the major inequalities affecting poor food producers. For both programs, Oxfam Novib is actively engaging with other donors working on the global level, as well as on program country and regional levels to fundraise and complement the proposed Sida funding. The overall ambition is the program to be implemented in more than 40 countries with a total budget of EUR 77 millions.
Oxfam Novib is part of the Oxfam confederation, an international confederation of 20 affiliates whose aim is to achieve greater impact by working together in collaboration with others. Oxfam Novib is the second-largest affiliate in the confederation and is responsible for providing business support and contracting of Oxfam staff in 14 developing and emerging countries. Oxfam Novib is also a partner affiliate in several other countries worldwide, contributing to the Oxfam country strategy with expertise, as well as implementing projects in those countries. Together, Oxfam works in over 90 countries and its affiliates share a common vision and philosophy to fight poverty and injustice, as part of a global movement for change.
The overall objective of SeedsGROW 2 is to contribute to a global food system that is just and sustainable, that supports the rights of small-scale food producers- men and women-, that guarantees food and nutrition security and that promotes the sustainable management of natural resources and biodiversity within the context of a changing climate. Oxfam has identified three main challenges related to SDGs and whose main aims are to create sustainability and ownership by the local or indigenous people; Sustainable Production Challenge - enough food must be produced at the same time as the planetary limits are not exceeded (SDG 2, 6, 12, 13, 14, 15); Resilience Challenge - The most vulnerable must be empowered to adapt to climate change and be compensated for the damages (SDG 1, 2, 13, 15); Equity Challenge - wealth and power need to be balanced in the food value chain (SDG 1, 5, 8, 9).
The target groups for both SD = HS and GROW are indigenous peoples and small farmers - women, men and youths. The components are: a). SD = HS is a multi-stakeholder initiative that bridges traditional and scientific knowledge for innovative and fair seed systems. SD = HS's focus is on improving locally produced seeds that are adapted to the needs and preferences of small-scale farmers and indigenous people. This helps to achieve food and nutrition safety both locally and globally, and that users can use their rights and have increased capacity to access, develop and use plant genetic resources.
The initiative's Theory of Change (ToC) shows how the four parts of the program are expected to lead to the goal and vision. The vision is a global food system that is fair and sustainable, which supports the rights and food security of locals while protecting natural resources, biodiversity in agriculture and adapting to climate change.
The objective of the program is that indigenous people enjoy their rights and have the capacity to access, develop and use plant genetic resources to improve their food security, including food nutritional value, despite climate change.
The four pillars of the program, including four outcomes in the theory of change, are expected to be mutually reinforcing and contribute to the overall objective.
Outcome / Pillar 1, Strengthening of Plant Diversity, aims to make indigenous peoples and small-scale communities more resistant through access to, use and management of plant genetic resources, both in terms of food safety, nutrition, disaster management and adaptation to climate change. Outcome / Pillar 2, Markets - aims to strengthen security of supply and secure access to seeds through the creation and availability of markets for high quality seeds adapted to farmers' needs. Outcome / Pillar 3 is called Neglected and Underutilized Species (NUS) - the expected result is to strengthen the resilience of local communities by increasing the nutritional value of food through the promotion of NUS, thereby strengthening biodiversity, which is also beneficial to health and community resilience. Outcome / Pillar 4, Policy and Institutions aims to provide stakeholders support for the possible political and institutional framework for banding seed systems and implementation of farmer’s rights.
b). GROW is an impact project aimed at changing the current food production system by encouraging and supporting public and private actors to revise policies and practices. Key areas to be addressed are land rights, climate change and inequalities in the food value chain. This is expected to benefit women small-scale food producers and their communities. The two components are separate from each other, but Sida will in dialogue with Oxfam Novib, encourage search for synergies based on expected results.
The vision for Grow II is the same as for SD = HS. Their Theory of Change (ToC) is problem-focused, focusing on female food producers and their local communities, which are increasingly affected by climate change, and have insecure land rights and incomes, as well as small opportunities for impact. The root causes are presented as three challenges in sustainable food production, resilience and gender equality with three focus areas for the project: food value chains, land rights and climate change. It is based on the assumption that progress in these areas gives tangible results for female farmers and their local communities within the defined challenges. The long-term goal of the initiative is to create a global movement for food justice with the goal of promoting private and public policies.
At global level, Oxfam Novib has the main responsibility for implementing activities and delivering results. The local-global links and activities in countries globally are diligently done by Oxfam. For SD = HS, Oxfam will collaborate with a wide range of strategic partners such as FAO, CGIAR, and seed companies. Within GROW, work is done with agricultural organizations and women producer groups, food retailers and food companies, public and private financial sectors and multilateral institutions. At the national level, project implementation will be done through Oxfam's national offices and partners for both project components.

The overall objective of the phase 2 programme is to contribute to a global food system that is just and sustainable, that supports the rights of small-scale food producers- men and women-, that guarantees food and nutrition security and that promotes the sustainable management of natural resources and biodiversity within the context of a changing climate. By the end of the project, women small-scale food producers will benefit from policy and practice change that empowers them to address injustices in the food value chains, increases their resilience to climate impacts and contribute to secure and equitable land rights. Medium to long term changes envisioned by SD=HS and which form the core of the Theory of Change are: Pillar 1: through self – sustaining Farmer Field Schools and over 35,000 grassroots master trainers, resilient indigenous and farming communities are better able to access and sustainably use plant genetic resources for food and nutrition security, climate change adaptation and disaster management. Pillar 2: by contributing towards a farmer inclusive market, indigenous peoples and small-holder farmers enhance their livelihoods, income and seed security through improved production of and improved policies on market access to high-quality seeds of diverse crops and varieties. Pillar 3: by understanding and addressing the hunger period, rural communities have strengthened their coping strategies by increasing the intake of nutritious food based on local biodiversity and improved management of neglected and underutilized species (NUS). Pillar 4: by providing evidence in support of farmers’ seed systems, Policy makers, seed industry and other stakeholders support an enabling policy and institutional environment for farmers’ seed systems and the implementation of Farmers’ Rights. Participatory Knowledge Management: though larger scale documentation, farmers’ access and use of information, and targeted communication materials, SD=HS will further enable reach out and facilitate exchange of knowledge and seed and foster greater cooperation of multiple stakeholders engaged in plant genetic resources for food and agriculture. By the end of the project at least 215,000 households in indigenous and farming communities will have benefitted. The target is that at least 50% of these beneficiaries will be women. The overall objective of the GROW project component is to contribute to a diverse and active movement for food justice across the world and to ensure women small-scale food producers and their communities benefit more from local, national and global public and private sector policies that ensure their food security and that protect and promote their prosperity and resilience. Long term changes envisioned by GROW are; globally and nationally operating food companies share power and wealth more equally in their supply chains, contributing to a poverty-free food system. Oxfam will encourage key private sector actors in the agri-food systems to improve their policies and practices in the areas of land rights, climate change and food value chains; public and private financial sector actors prioritize projects that support women small-scale food producers and their communities, that respect land rights and that are aligned with the goals of the Paris Agreement. Oxfam will engage with International Financial Institutions and other globally relevant Financial Institutions to ensure better alignment with international benchmarks, and leverage progress in their lending standards to encourage governments and others to do so; governments address the needs of women small-scale food producers and their communities, particularly those affected by climate change, through pro-poor climate adaptation plans, finance for irreversible loss and damage as result of climate change, and secure and equitable land rights. Sida assesses that the planned objectives of the intervention are plausible. There is simply a clear logic between the objectives.
